body.p:
I have before me your highly esteemed
favors 30th Decr. and Jany. 15th the latter to the care of Mr Solis
who I believe has left England for Holland. The first sight
of this gentleman operated upon my feelings as if he were a
connecting link between us two gratifying to me to converse
with one so intimate with yourself. Independent of his own
merits, he bringing a letter of Introduction from you insured him a
warm reception at my hands and he certainly has made a
favorable impression upon me and my family. I could have
wished to have paid him more attention than he has afforded me
the opportunity of doing, but hope when he returns to England
I shall see more of him. He has lunched twice with me at my
office in the city and dined once with us in upper Bedford place
where I hope I shall soon have the pleasure of his company
again and again.

The Jewish Chronicle No 14 contains nearly the
whole of my letter to you of the 10th Septr and had the paper
been stamped I would have sent you by this oppory. I think
and I hope you'll be satisfied in the with the manner I do not
let you mention a name, not even that of Mr Carillon
and you'll see that I have suppressed personal matter.
The publication of my letter has made a great sensation and
you'll be surprised to learn that it is now being translated
into [Hebrew], into German and into French, this I tell you confidentially
I have nothing to do with its reprint into the Holy Tongue and
English, not so with the German and French, the letter will
appear in the Archive. In The last No of the Voice 99
headed "Secession and Retrocession" you'll not comprehend well
till you obtain the J Chronicle, the next No of which will

contain a reply to any letter to the Occident. The part improved
in my saying that burial was denied to Mr H Montefiore. On
this head the "Voice" reminds me of the information he gave me on
that point, but he knows not that in consequence of that
very information I called on the nearest relations of the deceased
before I sent my letter to the Press. I knew that there were
some degrading terms annexed to the offer of burial which
the husband spurned and which terms had I touched upon
I must have made the pictures still darker! Three
years ago, in "Rejected Letters" I bring the same charges, denial
of burial, without naming the degrading terms. I have
thought it right to give you this information for the present,
my defence will appear when I have seen the charges.

And now, my dear Sir to your favor 30 Decr. which
needs but little by way of reply as I have no wish to keep up the
bell of Discussion on the very few points of disagreement and I feel
assured that even these few would be diminished could we discuss
the matter colloquially. I note all you say about Mr Marks and with
me the explanation rests. I was pleased to see his Sermon on the
Shemary[?] in the Occident—your Note has been transferred to the
Voice. No Sir! Your candour does not offend me, as friends we
must agree to differ. Thanks for your congratulations on my
daughter's matrimonial engagement. A few words will suffice
in reply to your last. Thanks for the portions you gave of my long
letter in No 22 and for the insertion of the whole of the short one.
Your appended remarks to my communications do not call for reply
but you have my thanks for offering me the oppory. to do so if I wish.
Do not hesitate a moment when you wish to give any friend a letter of introduction
to me. That the Almighty may accord you all your wishes in the
sincere prayer of My dear Sir. Yours very Truly

I have given to a friend some of the Jewish Chronicle
No 14[?] who promises to send them to New York to be
forwarded to your address B. E.
